A081706.name: Numbers n such that binary representation ends either in an odd number of ones followed by one zero or in an even number of ones.

A081708.name: a(n) = a(n-1) + 64*a(n-2) starting with a(0) = 2 and a(1) = 1.

A081709.name: Decimal expansion of lim_{i->infinity} Product_{j=2..i} gamma(i+zeta(i+1))/gamma(i+zeta(i)).

A081710.name: n! + n# + 1 is prime, where n# is the primorial function.

A081711.name: n! + n# - 1 is prime, where n# is the primorial function.

A081712.name: n! - n# + 1 is prime, where n# is the primorial function.

A081713.name: n! - n# - 1 is prime, where n# is the primorial function.

A081714.name: a(n) = F(n)*L(n+1) where F=Fibonacci and L=Lucas numbers.

A081715.name: Numbers n such that 3^n+2 is a semiprime.

A081716.name: Smallest number x such that phi(x)=A000010(x) has exactly n different decimal digits.

A081717.name: Primes p[j] such that p[j]+j is composite.

A081718.name: Array T(m,n) read by antidiagonals, where T(m,n) = number of m X infinity multiplicity integer partition (mip) matrix of n (m >= 0, n >= 0).
formula: There is a recurrence involving the partition function.

A081719.name: Triangle T(n,k) read by rows, related to Faà di Bruno's formula (n >= 0 and 0 <= k <= n).
formula: There is a recurrence involving the partition function A008284.

A081720.name: Triangle T(n,k) read by rows, giving number of bracelets (turnover necklaces) with n beads of k colors (n >= 1, 1 <= k <= n).
formula: T(n,k) = ((1+k)*k^{n/2}/2 + (1/n)*Sum_{d|n} phi(n/d)*k^d)/2, if n is even, and = (k^{(n+1)/2} + (1/n)*Sum_{d|n} phi(n/d)*k^d)/2, if n is odd.
G.f. for column k: (1/2)*((k*x+k*(k+1)*x^2/2)/(1-k*x^2) - Sum_{n>=1} (phi(n)/n)*log(1-k*x^n)) provided we chop off the Taylor expansion starting at x^k (and ignore all the terms x^n with n<k).

A081721.name: Number of bracelets of n beads in up to n colors.

A081722.name: Row sums of triangle in A081720.

A081723.name: Let b(n)=floor((3/2)^n), c(n)=floor((4/3)^n); sequence gives values of n such that b(n+1)/b(n)=3/2 and c(n+1)/c(n)=4/3.
formula: It seems that a(n) is asymptotic to C*n where 12<=C<=13

A081724.name: Let b(n)=floor((3/2)^n), c(n)=floor((4/3)^n), d(n)=floor((5/4)^n); sequence gives values of n such that b(n+1)/b(n)=3/2, c(n+1)/c(n)=4/3 and d(n+1)/d(n)=5/4.
formula: It seems that a(n) is asymptotic to C*n where C is around 60.

A081726.name: Let f(x,y)=floor((1+1/y)^x); sequence gives least k such that f(k+2,n)/f(k,n)=(1+1/n)^2.

A081727.name: Length of periods of Euler numbers modulo n.

A081728.name: Length of periods of Euler numbers modulo prime(n).

A081729.name: Expansion of Sum(k>=0, x^(2^k)) + 1/(1+x). First differences of A007456 (gossip sequence) for n>1.

A081730.name: Numbers n such that the n-th Euler number == 1 (mod n).
formula: All primes, all power of 2 are in the sequence. The composites are in A035163.

A081732.name: Number of numbers that differ from n in ternary representation by exactly one edit-operation: deletion, insertion, or substitution.

A081733.name: Triangle read by rows, T(n,k) = 2^(n-k)*[x^k] Euler_polynomial(n, x), for n >= 0, k >= 0.
formula: T(n,k) = C(n,k)*2^(n-k)*E_{n-k}(0) where C(n,k) is the binomial coefficient and E_{m}(x) are the Euler polynomials. - _Peter Luschny_, Jan 25 2009
Matrix inverse is A119468 and central column is A214447. - _Peter Luschny_, Jul 18 2012
Let skp{n}(x) denote the Swiss-Knife polynomials A153641. Then T(n,k) = [x^(n-k)]((skp{n}(x-1) - skp{n}(x+1))/2 + x^n). - _Peter Luschny_, Jul 22 2012

E.g.f.: [2/(e^(2t)+1)] e^(tx) = e^(P.(x)t), so this is an Appell sequence with lowering operator D = d/dx and raising operator R = x - 2/[e^(-2D)+1], i.e., D P_n(x) = n P_{n-1}(x) and R p_n(x) = P_{n+1}(x). Also, (P.(x)+y)^n = P_n(x+y), umbrally. R = x - 1 - D + 2 D^3/3! + ... contains the e.g.f.(D) mod signs of A009006 and A155585 and signed, aerated A000182, the zag numbers, and P_n(0) are the coefficients (mod signs/shift) of these sequences. The polynomials PI_n(x) of A119468 are the umbral compositional inverses of this sequence, i.e., P_n(PI.(x)) = x^n = PI_n(P.(x)) under umbral composition. Note that 2/[e^(2t)+1] = 2 Sum_{n >= 0} Eta(-n) (-2t)^n/n!], where Eta(s) is the Dirichlet eta function, and b_n = 2 *(-2)^n Eta(-n) = (-1)^n (2^(n+1)-4^(n+1)) Zeta(-n) = (2^(n+1)-4^(n+1)) B(n+1)/(n+1) with Zeta(s), the Riemann zeta function, and B(n), the Bernoulli numbers, so P_n(x) = (b. + x)^n, as an Appell polynomial. - _Tom Copeland_, Sep 27 2015

A081734.name: First and smallest sequence of 6 consecutive primes in arithmetic progression.

A081735.name: Numbers n such that the n-th Motzkin number == 1 (mod n).

A081736.name: Numbers n such that n is not an odd prime and not a square of prime and the n-th Motzkin number == 1 (mod n).

A081737.name: a(n) = (n-1)*10 + n-th decimal digit of Pi=3.14159...

A081738.name: Sum_{ 2 <= p <= n, p prime } p^2.

A081740.name: 11-level labeled rooted trees with n leaves.

A081741.name: Numbers n such that n divides A005554(n) (the sum of consecutive Motzkin numbers).
formula: All power of 3 are in the sequence.

A081742.name: a(1)=1; then if n is a multiple of 3 a(n)=a(n/3)+1, if n is not a multiple of 3 but even a(n)=a(n/2)+1, a(n)=a(n-1)+1 otherwise.

A081743.name: a(1)=1 then a(n)=a(n/2^k)+1 if n is even and 2^k is the largest power of 2 dividing n, a(n)=a(n-1) otherwise.

A081746.name: a(1)=1; for n>1, a(n)=a(n-1)-3 if n is already in the sequence, a(n)=a(n-1)+5 otherwise.
formula: a(n) - n is periodic with period 648.

A081751.name: a(n) is the smallest number that is precisely n-tuply abundant.

A081752.name: Ordered product of the sides of primitive Pythagorean triangles divided by 60.

A081753.name: a(n) = floor(n/12) if n==2 (mod 12); a(n)=floor(n/12)+1 otherwise.
formula: a(n) = floor(n/12) if n==2 (mod 12); a(n) = floor(n/12) + 1 otherwise.

A081754.name: Numbers n such that the number of noncongruent solutions to x^(2^m) == 1 (mod n) is the same for any m>=1.

A081755.name: Number of noncongruent solutions to x^(2^m) == 1 (mod n) when n is such that the number of solutions is the same for any m>=1.

A081756.name: Numbers n such that there is a proper divisor d of n satisfying sigma(d)=n.
formula: Multiply A007691 by A054030 and sort the resulting sequence. - _David Wasserman_, Jun 28 2004

A081757.name: Number of ways to write n as i*j+i-j, 0<i<j.

A081758.name: Sum of prime factors (with repetition) of sum of prime factors (with repetition) of n.

A081759.name: Numbers n such that 5n+6 is prime.

A081760.name: Decimal expansion of Landau's constant L.
formula: It is conjectured that L = 0.5432589653429767... = Gamma(1/3)*Gamma(5/6)/Gamma(1/6).

A081761.name: Least number >n having same type of prime factorization, a(1)=1.

A081762.name: Primes p such that p*(p-2) divides 2^(p-1)-1.

A081763.name: Primes p such that p*(p-1) divides 3^(p-1)-1.

A081764.name: Primes p such that p*(p-2) divides 3^(p-1)-1.

A081766.name: Numbers n such that n^2+1 divides C(2n,n).

A081767.name: Numbers n such that n^2-1 divides binomial(2n,n).

A081768.name: Number of k, 1<=k<=n, such that C(n,k) divides C(2n,2k).

A081769.name: a(n)-th term of the continued fraction for sum(k>=0,1/2^(2^k)) is 2.
formula: a(n)=5*n + 0 or + 3 and it appears that a(n)=5*n+3*A073089(n+2)

A081778.name: Maximum element is the continued fraction for n*sum(k>=0,1/2^(2^k)).

A081779.name: Ordered m for which m = k^3*a*b*(a^4 - b^4) determine (unique) solution triples(k,a,b), where k=1,2,3,... and (a,b) are coprime pairs, not both odd (i.e., of opposite parity).

A081780.name: Continued cotangent for square root of 3.
formula: sqrt(3)=cot(sum(n>=0, n, (-1)^n*acot(a(n))); let b(0)=sqrt(3), b(n)=(b(n-1)*floor(b(n-1))+1)/(b(n-1)-floor(b(n-1)) then a(n)=floor(b(n))

A081781.name: Continued cotangent for square root of 5.
formula: sqrt(5)=cot(sum(n>=0, n, (-1)^n*acot(a(n))); let b(0)=sqrt(3), b(n)=(b(n-1)*floor(b(n-1))+1)/(b(n-1)-floor(b(n-1)) then a(n)=floor(b(n))

A081782.name: Continued cotangent for the Gamma constant.
formula: Gamma=cot(sum(n>=0, n, (-1)^n*acot(a(n))); let b(0)=Gamma, b(n)=(b(n-1)*floor(b(n-1))+1)/(b(n-1)-floor(b(n-1)) then a(n)=floor(b(n))

A081783.name: Continued cotangent for zeta(2)=Pi^2/6.
formula: Pi^2/6=cot(sum(n>=0, n, (-1)^n*acot(a(n))); let b(0)=Pi^2/6, b(n)=(b(n-1)*floor(b(n-1))+1)/(b(n-1)-floor(b(n-1)) then a(n)=floor(b(n))

A081784.name: Continued cotangent for zeta(3).
formula: zeta(3)=cot(sum(n>=0, n, (-1)^n*acot(a(n))); let b(0)=zeta(3), b(n)=(b(n-1)*floor(b(n-1))+1)/(b(n-1)-floor(b(n-1)) then a(n)=floor(b(n))

A081785.name: Continued cotangent for log(2).
formula: log(2)=cot(sum(n>=0, n, (-1)^n*acot(a(n))); let b(0)=log(2), b(n)=(b(n-1)*floor(b(n-1))+1)/(b(n-1)-floor(b(n-1)) then a(n)=floor(b(n))

A081786.name: Continued cotangent for log(3).
formula: log(3)=cot(sum(n>=0, n, (-1)^n*acot(a(n))); let b(0)=log(3), b(n)=(b(n-1)*floor(b(n-1))+1)/(b(n-1)-floor(b(n-1)) then a(n)=floor(b(n))

A081787.name: Continued cotangent for sqrt(e).
formula: sqrt(e)=cot(sum(n>=0, n, (-1)^n*acot(a(n))); let b(0)=sqrt(e), b(n)=(b(n-1)*floor(b(n-1))+1)/(b(n-1)-floor(b(n-1)) then a(n)=floor(b(n)).

A081788.name: Continued cotangent for sin(1).
formula: sin(1)=cot(sum(n>=0, n, (-1)^n*acot(a(n))); let b(0)=sin(1), b(n)=(b(n-1)*floor(b(n-1))+1)/(b(n-1)-floor(b(n-1)) then a(n)=floor(b(n)).

A081789.name: Continued cotangent for cos(1).
formula: cos(1)=cot(sum(n>=0, n, (-1)^n*acot(a(n))); let b(0)=cos(1), b(n)=(b(n-1)*floor(b(n-1))+1)/(b(n-1)-floor(b(n-1)) then a(n)=floor(b(n)).

A081790.name: Continued cotangent for tan(1).
formula: tan(1)=cot(sum(n>=0, n, (-1)^n*acot(a(n))); let b(0)=tan(1), b(n)=(b(n-1)*floor(b(n-1))+1)/(b(n-1)-floor(b(n-1)) then a(n)=floor(b(n))

A081791.name: Continued cotangent for sinh(1).
formula: sinh(1)=cot(sum(n>=0, n, (-1)^n*acot(a(n))); let b(0)=sinh(1), b(n)=(b(n-1)*floor(b(n-1))+1)/(b(n-1)-floor(b(n-1)) then a(n)=floor(b(n))

A081792.name: Continued cotangent for cosh(1).
formula: cosh(1)=cot(sum(n>=0, n, (-1)^n*acot(a(n))); let b(0)=cosh(1), b(n)=(b(n-1)*floor(b(n-1))+1)/(b(n-1)-floor(b(n-1)) then a(n)=floor(b(n))

A081793.name: Continued cotangent for tanh(1).
formula: tanh(1)=cot(sum(n>=0, n, (-1)^n*acot(a(n))); let b(0)=tanh(1), b(n)=(b(n-1)*floor(b(n-1))+1)/(b(n-1)-floor(b(n-1)) then a(n)=floor(b(n))

A081794.name: Continued cotangent for Pi/4.
formula: Pi/4=cot(sum(n>=0, n, (-1)^n*acot(a(n))); let b(0)=Pi/4, b(n)=(b(n-1)*floor(b(n-1))+1)/(b(n-1)-floor(b(n-1)) then a(n)=floor(b(n))

A081795.name: Continued cotangent for Pi/3.
formula: Pi/3=cot(sum(n>=0, n, (-1)^n*acot(a(n))); let b(0)=Pi/3, b(n)=(b(n-1)*floor(b(n-1))+1)/(b(n-1)-floor(b(n-1)) then a(n)=floor(b(n))

A081796.name: Continued cotangent for sin(Pi/3)=sqrt(3)/2.
formula: sqrt(3)/2=cot(sum(n>=0, n, (-1)^n*acot(a(n))); let b(0)=sqrt(3)/2, b(n)=(b(n-1)*floor(b(n-1))+1)/(b(n-1)-floor(b(n-1)) then a(n)=floor(b(n))

A081797.name: Maximal coefficient (in absolute value) of the minimal polynomial P with integer coefficients such that P(sin(Pi/n)) = 0.

A081798.name: a(n) = Sum_{k = 0..n} C(n,k) * C(n+k,k) * C(n+2*k,k).
formula: a(n) = w(n,n,n) where w(i,j,k)=w(i-1,j,k)+w(i,j-1,k)+w(i,j,k-1)+w(i-1,j-1,k-1) and where w(0,0,0)=1 and w(i,j,k)=0 if one of i,j,k is strictly negative. - _Theodore Kolokolnikov_, Jul 04 2010
a(n) = Sum_{k = 0..n} multinomial(n + 2*k, k, k, k, n - k). Cf. A001850(n) = Sum_{k = 0..n} multinomial(n + k, k, k, n - k).
exp( Sum_{n >= 1} a(n)*x^n/n ) = 1 + x + 4*x^2 + 42*x^3 + 639*x^4 + 11571*x^5  + ... appears to have integer coefficients. (End)

A081799.name: Decimal expansion of the electric permittivity of vacuum in SI units as defined before 20 May 2019.
formula: Equals 10^6/(A019694*A003678^2). - _R. J. Mathar_, May 05 2006; corrected by _Arkadiusz Wesolowski_, Feb 03 2017
Explicitely: 1/([magnetic_permeability of vacuum]*[speed_of_light in vacuum]^2). - _Stanislav Sykora_, Jun 16 2012

A081800.name: Decimal expansion of atomic unit of velocity in SI units (meters/second).
formula: sqrt(H/m) where H = 4.359743...*10^-18 J is one Hartree and m = A081801. - _R. J. Mathar_, Feb 06 2009
V_n1 = alpha * c = A003673 * A003678. - _Omar E. Pol_, Nov 07 2013

A081801.name: Decimal expansion of electron mass in kg.

A081803.name: Decimal expansion of Compton electron radius in meters.

A081804.name: Hypotenuses of primitive Pythagorean triangles sorted on semiperimeter.

A081805.name: a(n) = n minus (largest prime power in n factorization); a(1) = 0.

A081806.name: Least positive number that can be written using prime factors of n (with repetition) and the operations add and subtract.

A081807.name: Numbers k such that the largest prime power factor of k equals floor(sqrt(k)).

A081808.name: Numbers n such that the largest prime power in the factorization of n equals phi(n).

A081810.name: If n = p_1^e_1 * ... * p_k^e_k, p_1 < ... < p_k primes, then a(n) = Max{ p_i*e_i }.

A081811.name: If n = p_1^e_1 * ... * p_k^e_k, p_1 < ... < p_k primes, then a(n) = min{ p_i*e_i }.

A081812.name: If n = p_1^e_1 * ... * p_k^e_k, p_1 < ... < p_k primes, then a(n) = Max{ Max(p_i, e_i) }.

A081813.name: Decimal expansion of atomic mass constant energy equivalent in MeV.

A081815.name: Decimal expansion of electron charge to mass quotient (negated)

A081817.name: Electron mass energy equivalent in MeV.

A081819.name: Decimal expansion of Wien displacement law constant.

A081820.name: Decimal expansion of the Stefan-Boltzmann constant sigma in the 2019 SI system in units Watt/(m^2*K^4).

A081823.name: Decimal expansion of the elementary charge e in coulomb (C).

A081824.name: Decimal expansion of conductance quantum in units of S.

A081825.name: Decimal expansion of atomic mass constant, in kg.

A081828.name: Numbers n such that 2 successive terms of Hofstadter Q-sequence are the same.

A081829.name: Numbers n such that the n-th term of Hofstadter Q-sequence is > (n+1)-th term.

A081830.name: Numbers n such that the n-th term of Hofstadter Q-sequence is < (n+1)-th term.

A081832.name: a(1)=a(2)=1, a(n) = a(n+1-2*a(n-1)) + a(n-2*a(n-2)).
formula: a(n+1)-a(n)=1 or 0, see Links section for proof. - _Altug Alkan_, Jun 07 2018

A081833.name: Least number resolvable into three factors in n distinct ways, or 0 if no such number exists.

A081834.name: a(1)=1, a(n)=a(n-1)+4 if n is already in the sequence, a(n)=a(n-1)+3 otherwise.

A081835.name: a(1)=1, a(n) = a(n-1) + 5 if n is already in the sequence, a(n) = a(n-1) + 4 otherwise.

A081836.name: Let z(n) be the golden ratio (phi) truncated to n decimal digits; sequence gives maximum element in the continued fraction for z(n).

A081837.name: Let z(n) be e=2.7182.... truncated to n decimal digits; sequence gives maximum element in the continued fraction for z(n).

A081838.name: Let z(n) be the golden ratio truncated to n decimal digits; sequence gives n such that the last element in the continued fraction for z(n) is 2.

A081839.name: a(1)=0, a(n)=a(n-1)+4 if n is already in the sequence, a(n)=a(n-1)+5 otherwise.

A081840.name: a(1)=0, a(n)=a(n-1)+3 if n is already in the sequence, a(n)=a(n-1)+4 otherwise.

A081841.name: a(1)=0, a(n)=a(n-1)+3 if n is already in the sequence, a(n)=a(n-1)+2 otherwise.
formula: a(1)=0; for n>=1 a(n)=floor(r*n-(4*r-1)/(r+1)) where r=1+sqrt(2)

A081842.name: a(1)=0, a(n)=a(n-1)+4 if n is already in the sequence, a(n)=a(n-1)+3 otherwise.

A081843.name: a(1)=0, a(n)=a(n-1)+5 if n is already in the sequence, a(n)=a(n-1)+4 otherwise.

A081844.name: Number of irreducible factors of x^(2n+1) - 1 over GF(2).
formula: a(n) = sum_{ d| 2*n+1 } phi(d)/ord_2(d), where phi = A000010, ord_2 = A002326.

A081845.name: Decimal expansion of Product_{k>=0} (1 + 1/2^k).
formula: lim sup Product_{k=0..floor(log_2(n))} (1 + 1/floor(n/2^k)) for n-->oo. - _Hieronymus Fischer_, Aug 20 2007
lim sup A132369(n)/A098844(n) for n-->oo. - _Hieronymus Fischer_, Aug 20 2007
lim sup A132269(n)/n^((1+log_2(n))/2) for n-->oo. - _Hieronymus Fischer_, Aug 20 2007
lim sup A132270(n)/n^((log_2(n)-1)/2) for n-->oo. - _Hieronymus Fischer_, Aug 20 2007
Equals 2*(-1/2; 1/2)_{infinity}, where (a;q)_{infinity} is the q-Pochhammer symbol. - _G. C. Greubel_, Dec 20 2015

A081846.name: Maximal element in the continued fraction for 1/n*sum(k>=0,1/2^(2^k)).

A081847.name: a(1) = 1, a(n) = smallest positive number such that the concatenation of a(n-1) and a(n) is a triangular number not obtained earlier.

A081848.name: Number of numbers with property that their base 3/2 expansion (see A024629) has n digits.

A081849.name: Consider recurrence b(0) = (2n+1)/2, b(n) = b(0)*ceiling(b(n-1)); sequence gives first integer reached.

A081850.name: Consider recurrence b(0) = (2n+1)/4, b(n) = b(0)*ceiling(b(n-1)); sequence gives number of steps to reach an integer (or -1 if no integer is ever reached).

A081851.name: Consider recurrence b(0) = (2n+1)/4, b(n) = b(0)*ceiling(b(n-1)); sequence gives first integer reached (or -1 if no integer is ever reached).

A081852.name: Consider recurrence b(0) = n/3, b(n) = b(0)*ceiling(b(n-1)); sequence gives first integer reached (or -1 if no integer is ever reached).

A081853.name: Consider recurrence b(0) = (2n+1)/2, b(n) = b(n-1)*ceiling(b(n-1)); sequence gives first integer reached.

A081855.name: Decimal expansion of Gamma''(1).
formula: The second derivative of Gamma(x) at x=1 is Gamma^2+zeta(2) = 1.97811199... where Gamma is the Euler constant and zeta(2) = Pi^2/6.

A081857.name: Jacobsthal sequence (A001045) as represented in base 4.
formula: For n > 0, a(2n) is represented as a string of n 1's and a(2n+1) as a string of (n-1) 2's followed by a 3.

A081858.name: Numbers n such that 2n+1 divides 2^n-1.
formula: n such that A002326(n)|n: since 2^n == 1 mod 2n+1, n must be a multiple of the order of 2 mod 2n+1.

A081859.name: Short leg of primitive Pythagorean triangles sorted on semiperimeter.

A081863.name: Largest integer m such that m divides (sigma_(2n+1)(2k-1)-sigma(2k-1)) for all k>=1.

A081864.name: Sum of 5th powers of the divisors of odd numbers: a(n) = sigma_5(2n-1).

A081868.name: Numbers k such that Sum_{j=1..k} (binomial(2*j,j) mod 3) is even.

A081869.name: a(1)=2; for n>1, a(n)=2*a(n-1)-1 if that number is composite, a(n)=a(n-1)+1 otherwise.
formula: a(n)=s(n)*2^c(n) where c(n) is an integer sequence and s(n) converges to 1.422004961641565758470595....

A081870.name: a(1)=1, a(n)=2*a(n-1)+1 if that number is not squarefree, a(n)=a(n-1)+1 otherwise.
formula: a(n)=r(n)*2^b(n) where b(n) is an integer sequence and r(n) converges to 1.124922752241150441104513529....

A081871.name: a(1)=1, a(n)=2*a(n-1)+1 if that number is composite, a(n)=a(n-1)+1 otherwise.
formula: a(n)=r(n)*2^b(n) where b(n) is an integer sequence and r(n) converges to 1.452148914690155834251....

A081872.name: Long legs of primitive Pythagorean triangles sorted on semiperimeter.

A081873.name: Ordered semiperimeter of primitive Pythagorean triangles with an odd short leg (or an even long leg).

A081874.name: Ordered odd short legs of primitive Pythagorean triangles.

A081875.name: a(n) = Sum_{d|n} phi(n/d)*C(2*d,d)/2.
formula: Dirichlet convolution of A000010 and A088218. - _R. J. Mathar_, Mar 11 2017

A081876.name: a(n) is the starting position of the second occurrence of a string of the initial n decimal digits of Pi in the decimal expansion of Pi.

A081878.name: Triangle read by rows in which row n begins with n (n=1,2,3,...) and iterates the process of dividing n by 2 if n is even, adding 3 if n is an odd prime, otherwise adding 1; stopping when either 1 or 3 is reached.

A081879.name: Number of steps for convergence (to 1 or 3) for the process in A081878.

A081880.name: Triangle read by rows: n-th row gives trajectory of 2n under the map x->(x^2-4)/6, stopping when the next term would be negative or nonintegral.

A081881.name: Pack bins of size 1 sequentially with items of size 1/1, 1/2, 1/3, 1/4, ... . Sequence gives values of n for which 1/n starts a new bin.
formula: a(n) is asymptotic to C*exp(n) where C=0.1688... - _Benoit Cloitre_, Apr 14 2003
a(n) = 1 + (A136616^(n-1))(0), where (f^0)(x)=x, (f^(n+1))(x) = f((f^n)(x)) for any function f. - _Rainer Rosenthal_, Feb 16 2008, Apr 05 2020

A081882.name: Number of steps needed to reach an integer starting with n-1/4 and iterating the map x ->x*ceiling(x).
formula: It seems that sum(k=2, n, a(k)) is asymptotic to 3n

A081883.name: Numbers n such that the number of steps needed to reach an integer starting with n-1/4 or n+1/4 and iterating the map x-->x*ceiling(x) is the same.

A081884.name: Number of steps needed to reach an integer starting with n+1/8 and iterating the map x-->x*ceiling(x).
formula: It seems that sum(k=1, n, a(k)) is asymptotic to 4n.

A081885.name: Number of steps needed to reach an integer starting with n+1/16 and iterating the map x-->x*ceiling(x).
formula: It seems that sum(k=1, n, a(k)) is asymptotic to 5n.

A081887.name: Numbers k such that lcm(1..k) equals the denominator of the sum of the first k harmonic numbers.

A081888.name: Numbers n such that the least positive primitive root of n is larger than the value for all positive numbers smaller than n.
formula: Numbers 1, 2, 4, p^m and 2*p^m have primitive roots for odd primes p and m >=1 natural number.

A081889.name: Least primitive root corresponding to A081888(n).

A081908.name: a(n) = 2^n*(n^2 - n + 8)/8.
formula: a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} C(n, k)*(1 + C(k, 2)). - _Paul Barry_, May 27 2003

A081919.name: E.g.f.: exp(x)/sqrt(1-x^2).
formula: D-finite with recurrence: -a(n) +a(n-1) +(n-1)^2*a(n-2) -(n-1)*(n-2)*a(n-3)=0. - _R. J. Mathar_, Nov 09 2012
E.g.f. A(x) satisfies (1-x^2)*A'(x) - (1+x-x^2)*A(x) = 0, from which R. J. Mathar's recurrence follows. - _Robert Israel_, Feb 28 2016

A081920.name: Expansion of exp(2x)/sqrt(1-x^2).
formula: Conjecture confirmed using d.e. (x^2-1)*y' + (-2*x^2+x+2)*y = 0 satisfied by the E.g.f. - _Robert Israel_, Feb 19 2018

A081921.name: Expansion of exp(3x)/sqrt(1-x^2).
formula: Mathar's conjecture follows from the differential equation (-3*x^2+x+3)*y+(x^2-1)*y'=0 satisfied by the E.g.f. - _Robert Israel_, Mar 14 2019

A081922.name: Expansion of exp(4x)/sqrt(1-x^2).
formula: D-finite with recurrence: -a(n) + 4*a(n-1) + (n-1)^2*a(n-2) - 4*(n-1)*(n-2)*a(n-3) = 0. - _R. J. Mathar_, Nov 09 2012

A081923.name: Expansion of exp(2x)/(1-x)^2.
formula: E.g.f.: 1/U(0) where U(k)=   1 - 2*x/( 1 + x/(2 - x - 4/( 2 - x*(k+1)/U(k+1)))) ; (continued fraction, 3rd kind, 4-step). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Oct 28 2012
G.f.: 2/x/G(0) - 1/x, where G(k)= 1 + 1/(1 - x*(2*k+2)/(x*(2*k+4) - 1 + x*(2*k+2)/G(k+1))); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, May 31 2013
G.f.: (sum(k>=0, k!*(x/(1-2*x))^k ) - 1)/x = Q(0)/(2*x) - 1/x, where Q(k)= 1 + 1/(1 - x*(k+1)/(x*(k+1) + (1-2*x)/Q(k+1) )); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Aug 09 2013
G.f.: W(0)/x - 1/x, where W(k) = 1 - x*(k+1)/( x*(k+3) - 1/(1 - x*(k+1)/( x*(k+1) - 1/W(k+1) ))); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Aug 26 2013

Applying Maple's ZeilbergerRecurrence command to the above series of Walsh for a(n) results in the first-order recurrence equation (n - 1)*a(n+1) = n*(n + 1)*a(n) - 2^(n+2) with a(0) = 1 and a(2) = 18. Using this it is easy to verify that a(n) satisfies the second-order recurrence a(n) = (n + 3)*a(n-1) - 2*(n - 1)*a(n-2) conjectured above by Mathar.

The sequence b(n) = n!*(n - 1) satisfies the same second-order recurrence but with the initial conditions b(0) = -1 and b(1) = 0. This leads to the finite continued fraction expansion a(n)/b(n) = 9 - 2*( 4/(6 - 6/(7 - 8/(9 - ... - 2*n/(n + 4)))) ) valid for n >= 2. Letting n tend to infinity produces the infinite continued fraction expansion e^2 = 9 - 2*( 4/(6 - 6/(7 - 8/(9 - ... - 2*n/(n + 4 - ...)))) ). (End)

A081924.name: E.g.f.: exp(3*x)/(1-x)^2.
formula: Define f_1(x), f_2(x), ... such that f_1(x) = x*e^x, f_{n+1}(x) = (d/dx)(x*f_n(x)), for n=2,3,.... Then a(n-1) = e^{-1/2}*2^n*f_n(1/2). - _Milan Janjic_, May 30 2008
G.f.: 2/x/G(0) - 1/x, where G(k)= 1 + 1/(1 - x*(2*k+2)/(x*(2*k+5) - 1 + x*(2*k+2)/G(k+1))); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, May 31 2013
G.f.: G(0)/x - 1/x, where G(k) = 1 + (2*k + 1)*x/(1-3*x - 2*x*(1-3*x)*(k+1)/(2*x*(k+1) + (1-3*x)/G(k+1))); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jun 26 2013
E.g.f.: 1/E(0), where E(k) = 1 - 2*x/(1 - x/(x - 2 + 6/(3 - x*(k+1)/E(k+1)))); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jun 26 2013
G.f.: (Sum_{k>=0} (k!*(x/(1-3*x))^k) - 1)/x = Q(0)/(2*x) - 1/x, where Q(k) = 1 + 1/(1 - x*(k+1)/(x*(k+1) + (1-3*x)/Q(k+1))); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Aug 09 2013
a(n) ~ exp(3) * n! * n. - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Oct 05 2013

A081925.name: Ordered even short legs of primitive Pythagorean triangles.

A081926.name: Triangle read by rows in which n-th row gives n smallest numbers with digit sum n.

A081927.name: n-th positive integer whose digits sum up to n.

A081928.name: Sum of the n smallest numbers having the sum of their digits equal to n.

A081929.name: Sum of the n-th row of A077339.

A081930.name: Triangle read by rows in which row n gives n smallest palindromic numbers of n digits each.

A081932.name: Sum of n-th row of A081930.

A081933.name: a(1) = 1, a(n) is the smallest number coprime to n and beginning with a(n-1).

A081934.name: Ordered odd long legs of primitive Pythagorean triangles.

A081935.name: Ordered even long legs of primitive Pythagorean triangles.

A081936.name: Odd short legs of primitive Pythagorean triangles sorted on semiperimeter.

A081937.name: Even long legs of primitive Pythagorean triangles sorted on semiperimeter.

A081938.name: a(1) = 1, a(n) = smallest palindromic number > a(n-1) of the form k*a(n-1) - 1.

A081939.name: a(1) = 2; a(n+1) is the smallest palindrome > a(n) that has a common factor with a(n).

A081941.name: a(1) = 1; for n>1, a(n)= smallest number greater than the previous term such that a(n-1)*a(n) + 1 is a palindrome.

A081942.name: a(1) = 1, a(n) = smallest number greater than a(n-1) such that a(n-1)*a(n) + 1 is prime.

A081943.name: a(1) = 1, a(n)= smallest number not occurring earlier such that a(n-1)*a(n) -1 is a prime. re-arrangement of natural numbers such that the product of adjacent terms is one more than a prime.

A081944.name: Numbers k such that both k*(k+1) - 1 and k*(k-1) - 1 are primes.

A081945.name: Numbers k such that both k*(k + 1) + 1 and k*(k - 1) + 1 are primes.

A081947.name: Smallest prime which is one more than the product of n distinct numbers.

A081948.name: Smallest square which is one more than the product of n distinct numbers > 1.

A081949.name: Smallest square which is one more than the product of n (not necessarily distinct) numbers > 1.

A081950.name: Smallest triangular number k such that k-1 has exactly n (not necessarily distinct) prime factors.

A081951.name: Smallest triangular number which is one more than the product of n distinct numbers > 1.

A081952.name: Smallest Fibonacci number which is one more than the product of n distinct numbers > 1.

A081953.name: Smallest Fibonacci number equal one plus the product of n (not necessarily distinct) integers > 1.
formula: a(n)=A000045(k) for the smallest k such that A001222(A000045(k)-1)>=n.

A081954.name: Triangle read by rows: T(n, k) = 2^(n-k)*3^k, n >= 1, 0 <= k < n.

A081955.name: a(n) = 2^r*3^s where r = n(n+1)/2 and s = n(n-1)/2.

A081957.name: Triangle whose n-th row contains the n smallest numbers that are products of n distinct integers > 1, read by rows.

A081961.name: Hypotenuses of primitive Pythagorean triangles with an odd short leg (or an even long leg) sorted on semiperimeter.

A081962.name: Ordered semiperimeters of primitive Pythagorean triangles with an even short leg (or an odd long leg).

A081963.name: Even short legs of primitive Pythagorean triangles sorted on semiperimeter.

A081964.name: In the following triangle the n-th row contains n numbers relatively prime to n and not occurring in a previous row. a(1) = 1. Sequence contains the triangle by rows.

A081971.name: Consider the harmonic progression 1,1/2,1/3,1/4,1/5,..., group the terms such that the n-th group contains n members like this (1/1),(1/2,1/3),(1/4,1/5,1/6), (1/7,1/8,1/9,1/10),... a(n) = the numerator of the reduced rational sum of the terms of the n-th group.

A081972.name: Consider the geometric progression 1,1/2,1/4,1/8,1/16,1/32,1/64,... Group the terms such that the n-th group contains n terms like this (1/1),(1/2,1/4),(1/8,1/16,1,32),(1/64,1/128,1/256,1/512),... a(n) = floor[1/s(n)] where s(n) is the sum of the members of the n-th group.

A081973.name: a(1) = 1; a(n) = a(n-1) + sigma(a(n-1)) where sigma(k) = sum of the divisors of k.

A081974.name: a(1) = 1 and smallest number not occurring earlier such that the product of two neighboring terms is a distinct triangular number, where "distinct" means that a(n)*a(n+1) may not equal the product of any two previous consecutive terms.

A081975.name: Triangular number pertaining to A081974. a(n) = A081974(n)*A081974(n+1).

A081976.name: For n > 2, a(n) is minimal so that the products of two adjacent terms are distinct Fibonacci numbers.
formula: a(n-1)*a(n) = A079613(n-2) = F(2^(n-2)*3), where F(k) is the k-th Fibonacci number.

A081977.name: Odd long legs of primitive Pythagorean triangles sorted on semiperimeter.

A081978.name: Smallest triangular number with exactly n divisors, or 0 if no such number exists.

A081979.name: Smallest Fibonacci number with 2n divisors, or 0 if no such number exists.

A081980.name: a(n) = numerator of the sum of the reciprocals of the n primes from prime(n(n-1)/2+1) to prime(n(n+1)/2).

A081981.name: Primes p such that p+1 is divisible by every nonzero digit of p.

A081982.name: Primes p such that p+1 is divisible by the digital product (of nonzero digits) of p.

A081983.name: Primes p such that p-1 is divisible by every nonzero digit of p.

A081984.name: Primes p such that p-1 is divisible by the digital product ( of nonzero digits) of p.

A081985.name: Hypotenuses of primitive Pythagorean triangles with even short leg (or odd long leg) sorted on semiperimeter.

A081986.name: a(n) = {A081984(n)-1}/d, where d is the product of nonzero digits of A081984(n).

A081987.name: a(n) = {A081982(n)+1}/d, where d is the product of nonzero digits of A081982(n).

A081988.name: Product of digits + 1 is a prime.

A081989.name: Product of digits + 1 is a square.

A081990.name: Numbers k such that both k+1 and (product of digits of k) + 1 are squares.

A081991.name: Numbers in ascending order formed by using all the digits of the next n numbers.

A081992.name: a(n) = count of numbers formed using the digits of next n numbers..

A081993.name: a(n) = sum of numbers formed using the digits of next n numbers.

A081994.name: Triangle read by rows in which the n-th row contains n numbers not occurring earlier such that every entry is coprime to all the members of the row and column it belongs.

A081998.name: Square array read by antidiagonals, alternating upwards and downwards: T(i, j) is the least number that is greater than the previous term and coprime to every number on the same row or column.

A081999.name: First row of array in A081998.

A082000.name: First column of array in A081998.
